lecture 24: Derivatives and Graphs of Functions

How Derivatives Shape Graphs

  • First Derivative f′(x)f'(x)f′(x): Tells us where a function is increasing or decreasing.
  • Second Derivative f′′(x)f''(x)f′′(x): Tells us about concavity and inflection points.

Knowing f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) and f′′(x)f''(x)f′′(x) helps us understand the shape and features of a graph.

First Derivative Test

1. Critical Points

  • Points where f′(x)=0f'(x) = 0f′(x)=0 or f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) is undefined.

2. Increasing / Decreasing Behavior

  • If f′(x)>0f'(x) > 0f′(x)>0 on an interval ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ function is increasing there.
  • If f′(x)<0f'(x) < 0f′(x)<0 on an interval ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ function is decreasing there.

3. Local Max/Min

  • If f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) changes from positive to negative ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ local max
  • If f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) changes from negative to positive ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ local min

Example:
f(x)=x3−3x2+2f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 + 2f(x)=x3−3x2+2
f′(x)=3x2−6xf'(x) = 3x^2 - 6xf′(x)=3x2−6x
Critical points at x=0x = 0x=0, x=2x = 2x=2
Use sign chart to determine max/min

Second Derivative Test

1. Concavity

  • If f′′(x)>0f''(x) > 0f′′(x)>0 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ graph is concave up (∪\cup∪-shape)
  • If f′′(x)<0f''(x) < 0f′′(x)<0 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ graph is concave down (∩\cap∩-shape)

2. Inflection Points

  • Points where f′′(x)=0f''(x) = 0f′′(x)=0 and concavity changes

3. Alternative Max/Min Test

  • At a critical point x=cx = cx=c:
    • If f′′(c)>0f''(c) > 0f′′(c)>0 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ local min
    • If f′′(c)<0f''(c) < 0f′′(c)<0 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ local max
    • If f′′(c)=0f''(c) = 0f′′(c)=0 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ test is inconclusive

Example:
f(x)=x4−4x2f(x) = x^4 - 4x^2f(x)=x4−4x2
f′(x)=4x3−8xf'(x) = 4x^3 - 8xf′(x)=4x3−8x
f′′(x)=12x2−8f''(x) = 12x^2 - 8f′′(x)=12x2−8
Critical points at x=0x = 0x=0, x=±2x = \pm 2x=±2
Inflection points at x=±23x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}x=±32​​
At x=0x = 0x=0, f′′(x)=−8<0⇒f''(x) = -8 < 0 \Rightarrowf′′(x)=−8<0⇒ local max
At x=±2x = \pm 2x=±2, f′′(x)=40>0⇒f''(x) = 40 > 0 \Rightarrowf′′(x)=40>0⇒ local min

Graph Sketching Strategy

  1. Find domain
  2. Find intercepts (of x-axis and y-axis)
  3. Find critical points from f′(x)f'(x)f′(x)
  4. Use f′′(x)f''(x)f′′(x) to determine concavity
  5. Find asymptotes (if any)
  6. Combine all info for a full sketch

Helpful tip: Create a sign chart for f′f'f′ and f′′f''f′′.

Example Problem

Given: f(x)=x3−6x2+9x+1f(x) = x^3 - 6x^2 + 9x + 1f(x)=x3−6x2+9x+1

  1. f′(x)=3x2−12x+9f'(x) = 3x^2 - 12x + 9f′(x)=3x2−12x+9
  2. Critical points: x=1x = 1x=1, x=3x = 3x=3
  3. f′′(x)=6x−12f''(x) = 6x - 12f′′(x)=6x−12
  4. Inflection point: x=2x = 2x=2
Interval f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) Behavior f′′(x)f''(x)f′′(x) Concavity
(−∞,1)(-\infty, 1)(−∞,1) + Increasing - Concave Down
(1,2)(1, 2)(1,2) - Decreasing - Concave Down
(2,3)(2, 3)(2,3) - Decreasing + Concave Up
(3,∞)(3, \infty)(3,∞) + Increasing + Concave Up

Summary

  • First derivative: increasing/decreasing, local max/min
  • Second derivative: concavity, inflection points
  • Combine both to sketch better graphs

Exercises

1. First and Second Derivative Analysis

Given f(x)=x3−9x2+24xf(x) = x^3 - 9x^2 + 24xf(x)=x3−9x2+24x:

  • a) Find f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) and f′′(x)f''(x)f′′(x)
  • b) Identify intervals of increase/decrease
  • c) Find local extrema
  • d) Identify concavity and inflection points

2. Graph Sketching

Sketch a complete graph of:

  • a) f(x)=x2x2+1f(x) = \frac{x^2}{x^2 + 1}f(x)=x2+1x2​
  • b) f(x)=x4−4x2f(x) = x^4 - 4x^2f(x)=x4−4x2

3. Real-Life Interpretation

Suppose P(t)P(t)P(t) models population over time:

  • a) What does it mean if P′(t)>0P'(t) > 0P′(t)>0 but P′′(t)<0P''(t) < 0P′′(t)<0?
  • b) What does an inflection point mean in this context?

4. Build a Function

Create a polynomial function with:

  • A local max at x=−1x = -1x=−1
  • A local min at x=2x = 2x=2
  • An inflection point at x=0x = 0x=0
